options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned so much about music in such a short time. I have more confidence in my music theory knowledge!
The fundamentals of music theory (pretty hammered to my soul), pitches, intervals, chords, chord progressions, rhythm,  cadences!
Sight Reading, learned note scales, triads, 7 chords, rhythm
Reading music in both treble and bass clefs, basic rhythm, harmonic functions, cadences, scales and key signatures, seventh chords, sight singing, ear training
I learned about the basic elements of music, the structure of scales and chords and keys, and the basic structure of songs.
Basic skills in sight-reading, notation and composition

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strength: great practice in class and with worksheets, and Professor Lalli's practice recordings are super helpful
Weakness: honestly, sometimes we felt a little bullied in class even though I know it was meant to be playful when we answered incorrect questions.

Strength: I think the intro music theory is BY NATURE very boring, because essentially you need to learn a set of "music language" to start do things. MUSI 110 is teaching you such knowledge, and you need to learn it well so that the courses that follow are enjoyable. 

110 does teach it well. The progress speed is gentle and well-paced, and it all comes together in the end. Listening, singing, reading, quirky music history are mixed and make this class enjoyable at times. 

Weakness: 1. some people have significant music backgrounds and are still taking this class, which makes it a bit frustrating. 
2. the structure isn't very clear. I have no idea what my grades will be at all throughout the term. The worksheets are not graded, the midterms are take home so it's hard to gauge how I am doing. 3. Some people are seriously behind in this class, and I think the Prof. should figure out something to accommodate them, otherwise other people are just sitting around and feeling bored.
Some people already know this stuff so it discourages you if you dont get it as well as other, but the professor will work with you to catch up.

The small class size is perfect for facilitating understanding by every single person in the class. Prof. Lalli would cold call on each of us to answer questions that tested out understanding of the lesson, which some people dont like, but I thought was great because it was a supportive environment so it was effective in keeping us all on the same page and caught up.

It is a very good introductory course for beginners. It gets you up to speed very fast and lets someone go from no knowledge to a solid understanding of music. I do wish there was more discussion of song structure or songwriting, such as melody construction or chord progression. I understand it is an intro course, but I would have enjoyed more discussion of songwriting.

Strength: solid material taught by an experienced instructor who loves music and will make you do the same
Weakness: could have moved forward faster in theory at times instead of repeating drills

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Succeeded: practice recordings so students can hear and improve aural skills
Improving: maybe set higher expectations at the beginning of the course rather than later on. frankly, I was just doing the worksheets and all the bare minimum of work rather than trying hard to be a good musician, when expectations rose. but at the same time, us students must set our own expectations. virtual learning also took the classroom community away :(
Nothing. ZOOM worked fine.

This class is probably much better in-person because you can learn and be tested on keyboard skills, which was hard to do virtually. Otherwise, Professor Lalli did a good job with virtual lecture slides.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: There is a lot of work involved.

Yes! Music is so great, and students should learn some basic knowledge. Coming from an underprivileged high school, I did not have music theory courses and felt that I was too late taking music courses. But others are in the same boat. Lalli is so kind, too!

Yes! It's hard and requires loads of sitting down and figuring things out, but it's fun during class time and it all comes together in the end. 
Prof. Lalli is so lovable (he genuinely loves teaching this stuff) and so accessible.
Yes, great professor that cares and works with students
Yes. If youve never learned any music theory at all, this is a great class for you!

I would recommend this course to anyone who is not already proficient at music. Learning this stuff is really cool and exciting; it's interesting to see how the songs you know are made. This course is even good for someone who has played an instrument before but never really taken a class on theory, it really solidified my understanding of music.
YES

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: n/a
one to one meetings with Prof. Lalli
Mandatory one-on-one virtual meetings with the professor
